ifU7w-m9c_BYBjoccWXb8g.text: When I read about a Taiwanese bun house that had opened up close to work, I had to try it out. As I approached Lexington street I could see what looked like an ad hoc bus stop - it was in fact the queue for Bao! A bit anxious that this may take too long for a lunch break, I joined the ever growing queue. After a short while a Bao staff came out and took in the solo diners - including me!The restaurant atmosphere is cosy, and the staff members are polite. The menu is simplistic yet informative. I went for the crispy chicken with sesame buns with kimchi! Mmm! A small bun, but boy does it taste good! The peanut milk is also very cool and something I talk about at dinner gatherings a lot. Overall 4/5, as cost was a little high for what you get - getting there early for lunch is advised as the queue can grow very fast!

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Crispy chicken with kimchi!
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Peanut milk!
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. The simplistic menu

UcamOnavSdKUc78a6JwSUw.text: Great little place to go in Soho if you're craving some cheap and tasty small bites!We arrived at 8pm and there was a 30-40 minute wait. We followed suit with others in the queue who were grabbing drinks from the pub next door which was a great idea.. even if it did mean that we were a little tipsy by the time we were seated in the restaurant!We ordered quite a big variety of food as we were so hungry by the time we made it in. The spicy fried chicken and the pork 'nuggets' were pretty tasty. I'm not usually a fan of fried foods but the fried chicken tasted like good quality chicken breast (with no bones). We got an order of the sweet potato fries, which were coated in a light batter making them nice and crispy.My husbands favourite dish was the guinea fowl rice- it was very flavourful and came as quite a substantial portion. It does come with pickles on top which I found a little overpowering - I'd ask them to leave these off next time. My favourite dish was the scallop- it came served on a clam shell and had a really interesting zesty dressing!As for the bao, we shared a lamb bao and a confit pork bao. Both were delicious- the lamb bao has a Mediterranean flavour to it which I particularly enjoyed. We also finished with the ice cream bao. I have to say that I didn't love it.. but maybe I'm just not a huge fan of Horlicks..!Overall we had a really nice meal- we ordered one too many dishes for the two of us as we left feeling rather full! We will definitely be back, perhaps not at peak time as arguably I don't think it is worth a half hour wait...

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Guinea fowl rice dish, comes with raw egg
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Fried chicken- topped with a spicy sauce
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. One lamb and one confit pork bao!

h5tRYJ8Kl5ZEHiJizeaPkQ.text: Needed to have a very early dinner, so why not try a place you normally need to queue at? To Bao!I had had Bao's bao once before when they were a stall, I think at Netil Market. I remember thinking it was decent but not overwhelmingly better than, say, Yum Buns, which I love. I thought the restaurant was better than the stall. We had: Classic bun, pork confit, fried chicken bun, aubergine, house pickles, Taiwanese fried chicken, scallop. The scallop was tiny but really tasty. My fave buns were the classic and fried chicken buns, the tomato pickle, and my drink, a foaming (read: cream foam) cold tea. Really tasty. Bao was good, but I probably won't be consistently as it's not a ton of food for the price. But perhaps the occasional treat if you're not famished.

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom

5jujD-KV-95nhcpHyFxdSA.text: Only open a week and already a snaking queue at opening time for dinner tonight. That's partly due to the limited space inside this new restaurant but Bao have built a solid reputation from their previous ventures and there have already been some enthusiastic blog postingsI made sure to get there 20 minutes early and soon, the polite, friendly and very well informed staff were shepherding us to our tables. There's a mixture of small tables and counter seating. Decor is modern and pared down, which is reflected in the menuOrdering the Taiwanese street food is done by marking a menu card with pencil, which stays on the table. The staff then mark items off as the food arrives and you can use it to order more food. The eponymous bao come in 6 flavours, all explained on their own menu. I went for confit pork, which contained confit pork belly, pork sauce, hot sauce and dried shallots, all wrapped in their pillowy steamed buns. It was a lovely mouthful and the other diners on my table were going ga ga over the fried chicken baoThe staff recommended 2 dishes per person from the small plates section to accompany a bao. I chose the Taiwanese fried chicken with hot sauce due to my love of fried chicken. The thigh pieces had been deboned and fried in a crispy well flavoured batter though the smidgen of hot sauce could be more generousMy last dish grabbed at the extreme eater in me - pig blood cake. Described as Chinese black pudding mixed with glutinous rice, it arrived with an unexpected egg yolk on top. This dish didn't really work for me with the creamy yolk making the heavy cake taste even heavierHowever, there are so many more interesting dishes on the menu that I can't wait to come back and try. So, expect an update in the near future!

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Pig blood cake
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Taiwanese fried chicken

uxp_9fRNj9txU0WVVj9r_Q.text: My boyfriend (now husband) and I went to Bao for the First time and absolutely loved it! We each ordered about 3 different Baos, I ordered a  Beef soup and we shared the Taiwanese Fried chicken as a starter. We both loved the Fired chicken with hot sauce. - perfectly crunchy and delicious. I also ordered the peanut milk which had a nice subtle peanut flavour although it was slightly too sweet for my taste (I'm not used to much sugar so I'm sure for most it's lovely). We can't wait to go again and get a Bao Bag as well!

uxJsjTIq0VBesj_nU4X-ZA.text: Don't be intimidated by the long queue...you're in for some gooooooood shit.The boyfriend and I passed by this place in SoHo on a Wednesday night. I walked up to the door and just as I was about to open it, the host grabbed my attention and instructed me to turn around. Behind me, the queue was going down the street...ha.Fast forward fifteen minutes later, we were in. I think parties of more than two had to wait a considerably longer time, because the place is quite small to accommodate too many people at one table. The service was great from start to finish. The place is more tapas-style, so go ahead and order 3 dishes per person, maybe 4 if you've becoming ravenous from the queue. The waitress recommended to us a great sake (which happened to be the most expensive one ha ha ha), and we tried two of their baos: the Classic and the Confit Pork. Both were on point. The sweet potato chips were too good as well.I've had the hyped Eddie Huang's Baohaus several times in New York, but I think this Bao is better. I'll be back next time I touch down in London town.

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. aubergine
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Turnip tops, salted egg

Xa0FUfj41jdzpMTipluThw.text: What's not to love about hirata buns?  Fluffy white steamed buns filled with some kind of goodness.  So many places are popping up around London and I love trying the different flavours.  So we heard about the queues so we got there shortly before noon and already people are waiting to get in for lunch.  I know the place is small but do they really have to trickle people in so slowly?  We waited a good 20 minutes outside and finally get a seat for 3.  We shared the fried chicken and aubergine as starters.  The fried chicken was great but the aubergine was quite underwhelming.  Our baos took forever to come out.  I think they forgot about it but really does it take that long to pull this together?  I had the pork confit and lamb shoulder baos - both very tasty but thinking for what it is - I don't think it's worth the wait or the price.  I've had much better in street stalls - which I know thats how they started but seriously.  I don't think I wouldn't mind if we were able to get in quickly - order came out promptly.  Think it's over engineering something that should be quite simple.  Sorry Bao - I love the branding and all but probably won't be back.

THhG6VD8SKz1vJxCoJ82Mg.text: Holy smokes I have been here twice already in the space of a month, notwithstanding that horrendous long queue across the road. So how was it?MMm I kinda like Bao as you can get stuff here which reminds you of SE Asia which you can't really get anywhere else around Central London.Highly recommended items to order:Peanut Milk (Yes, a glass of milk, with peanuts in it)Horlicks Ice Cream (This reminds me of Fried Man Tou (buns) which Chinese people use condensed milk to dip into)Confit Pork bun - I love the almond toppings, gives it that hint of sweetness, beware sometimes this gets oilyThe aubergine crisps are quite cool to order once to try.I didn't like pig blood with the egg on it, sorry.Fried chicken was too deep fried for me. Also it was quite spicy.Service is fast. Place is tiny. If they didn't have fast service that queue outside will be even more horrendous.Come in a pair of 2. You will then get seated quickly. If you turn up at 11:50am you will get seated even more quickly. If you get there at 12:05 prepare to wait 10 minutes. Don't think that if you come at 9pm you will get seated quickly. No, there will still be a queue outside. All day long.There is one toilet and the way you get in reminds me of toilets on airplanes. Interesting!?PS: The lady who deals with the queue is so awesome.

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Scallop and classic pork bao
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Pork confit bao
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Lamb bun, minty but not my cup of tea

4h1LUbri562vSUwE7fHYlw.text: A solid 4 star place. Minus 1 star because they forgot some of the stuff on our order (twice), and let's be honest, this is pretty expensive place for what they serve. I'm from LA/SF and have been to Taiwan/China. These types of buns aren't rare in either Asia or California, so the price they charge here is definitely on the steeper end. Also, they charge £3 for beef soup. Don't get me wrong, the beef soup is good, but I've had equally good soup for way less. But maybe it's just the cost of living in London (though I thought, coming from San Francisco, cost of living should be similar). We tried basically everything on the menu (pork, chashu, lamb, chicken, dessert). So while the price is a bit high for my taste, it was very delicious and I would definitely revisit. One advice: come early. We came by around 20 minutes before opening and was able to make it to first seating (on a weekday). By the time the restaurant opened, the line was around the corner, and it was gonna be at least an hour to get in (if you come at that time). If it's your first time visiting and you have company, I would suggest try everything if you can, and get probably 3-4 buns per person. Every bun tastes delicious.

Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Lamb bao

TBPvt3ZCG2MFaJZ5kqDeUQ.text: Mmmmm good. You've probably heard the main con- if you don't go at an opportune time you will certainly wait for 30+ minutes- but once you're in you're treated to delicious steamed buns and other treats. My faves were the classic bao, fried chicken bao, and the fried chicken bites. It might get another 5 if they can lower the prices just a teensy bit and, for goodness sake, move to a larger location now that it is here to stay in London!

2K6m1iqiTgNK1TBD_UqGJw.text: Took 40min to serve and charged 12.50% for Discr. Service Charge  £1.94 for a £15.50 meal. Ridiculous.

L_2gy9EPgoksv5z4fa4k5w.text: Very pleasantly surprised.  The service was fantastic.  Showing up early is key as the queue tends to get quite long.  All of our dishes were unique and phenomenal.  I suggest the classic Bao and the house pickles.  The queue is on the other side of the street, so don't get confused and go to the door like so many!

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Classic Bao

By2hoQxgevYxheddcd8cUw.text: Very solid Thai food. Nothing crazy or particularly interesting about it but it was tasty. Service was good.

I3xZVobgL15iLrQxiCgcKw.text: An unassuming restaurant that we happened upon, as we were on our food crawl. Luckily we got here in the nick of time. 7 minutes later and the kitchen would have been closed.There's a great selection of items to try. Being on a crawl meant we limited ourselves to only 4 items. We went for the pickled veg, traditional pork bao, fried chicken and the fried ice cream holicks bao. We were not disappointed.When each of the dishes arrived in turn, there was something about the way the food was presented that made me feel excited to try it.Everything tasted exquisite. The steamed, pillowy, bread that cradled the succulent flavour filled pork is a must try item. The fried chicken was spicy and crunchy on the outside, yet meaty on the inside. The horlicks ice cream bao was the greatest way to round off the meal. The fried bread tasted like a doughnut and the horlicks flavour from the ice cream took me back to my childhood.The drinks, whilst small, were also worthy of a mention. We could see the bar from where we were sat and they looked to be made with great pride. I had a berry concoction whilst my fellow patron went for the lemon and lime To round it off we had the most lovely service, and it wasn't just the guy who seated us, or the lady who brought over our food or even just the lady who got us our bill. Everyone seemed to want to be there and provide a great service. Thank you for an amazing snack.

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Fried chicken
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Horlicks ice cream Bao

-Dl_o3_drGoxUfVZ_G94kw.text: This place has had such rave reviews that I have been nervous it may disappoint - IT DIDN'T!I finally got to go midweek after work with a friend and even then at just gone 6pm there is a queue of 10 or so people waiting to be seated - it is a small (& popular) place so it is understandable The queue does move fairly quickly however so we only had a 15 minute wait (I have heard people have waited over 30 minutes). You have to have your whole party their before you are seated which is standard but to be honest I don't think the venue is suitable for more than 4 people and even then it is a push, just because of the seating arrangements.Once seated with your menu you tick which items you want along with the quantity and hand it to the waiter asap (sort of like Ping Pong?). The menu is split between Bao's, sides and then other dishes. All the Bao's sounded amazing so I was keen to try as many as possible and the other half of the menu isn't really my thing (pig blood cake, century egg, trotter nuggets, soup) so we tried nearly all the bao's (£4-5 each) - Classic, Fried Chicken, Confit Pork & Lamb. We shared each, which is quite tricky as they are fairly small and there are no knives, but luckily we are good friends so don't mind! If on a date or with someone from work I would definitely stick to your own dishes. My favourite by far was the Lamb but also high up on the list was the Classic. We also got the sweet potato chips which were so good - super crispy!For pudding we got the Horlicks Bao - horlicks ice cream sandwiched between a fried bao (one each as that would have been impossible to share!) and boy was that a brilliant finish to the meal!We stuck with tap water throughout as weren't so fussed about trying their teas etc and in total it came to a reasonable-ish £30 I cannot wait to go back!

SJomShgJEE7cwSPC8tbx6g.text: One of the most interesting restaurant in LondonIt is surprising how smart they use ingredients to complement the food.Price: not expensive at all. What I had around 22£. You pay 30$ for a noodle soup and buns at Momofuku tho. What I had: - scallop. Scallop is nicely cook. I was noticed the green powder around the shell, and I gave my best guess: it tastes like seaweed powder. Those gave the scallop more sea flavor, if you add some of those on your scallop. - pig blood cake. I think this is alright. - trotter nuggets. Trotter is a common Chinese like food. However, the meat is tender on this part but if you eat too many trotter, the greasy taste will overwhelm you. The sauce (with some wasabi and something else I forgot) complement with the meat makes it perfect.- classic bun. The peanuts make it more tasty. - lamb shoulder bun. The green sauce is a finishing touch. I feel like there had cumin flavor in it. Lamb always go well with cumin. I think the restaurant used a lot Chinese cooking style and integrate them into a more western friendly dishes. Brilliant. Definitely will go again.

rAb0WHrGvv7E033K549d3A.text: After waiting nearly 2 hours in a queue, we managed to get in. After we got in, waited 20 min to order. After ordering we waited at least 30 min to get served. Taste was alright. Never again.I had to download yelp, to leave a review for the first time in my life

4P9i-LWSRtF2yAzWAlMeCQ.text: Small, cute, intimate. Tables are tiny and close to each other. My friend and I stopped by this place before our afternoon tea reservation at the Ritz. We had the classic bao, lamb bao, scallop, pork blood rice cake, and sweet potato fries. The bao and scallop tasted amazing. Egg yolk on top of pork blood rice cake was interesting and bouncy. Overall we were pleasantly surprised, whereas the afternoon tea afterwards was not to our expectations. We'll be back soon to try the others!

pIaprUjOEOHSFgXiSQVw9g.text: A place of mixed feelings. While there was a queue it was nice to have a Sam smith pint from the nearby John Snow while waiting.  After about a 25 minute wait on a Saturday night (less than the waiter told us) we sat in a cramped table and immediately ordered:Pickles- interesting flavors, sourClassic bao- good flavor combination of succulent pork and bread crumbs. Lamb shoulder bao- great meat and came with jalepeno kickPork confit bao- tasty but fattyBeef strips- disappointing dish, thin rare slices of beef with little flavor and far too much fat. Unfortunate as we were choosing between this and the fried chicken. Aubergine- tasty compote like dish on crunchy wonton. Ice cream bao- thought it was all fried, turned out to be creamy ice cream in between a fried bao. 2 Taiwan beers- at £4.5 per can as far less than a pint, hardly a deal Overall the baos were tasty, as well as the aubergine, but for over £40 for the meal, it seemed a little steep for street food. Also wish the couple next to us didn't comment o every dish we ordered.

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Beer beef and bao

8y39F8sxA2q7UdvvaSzdyQ.text: Following restaurants on Instagram can be torture.  Constantly looking at pictures on your newsfeed can make you want to almost consume your phone at times.  However, once I booked my ticket to London, the realization of actually eating a bao was shortly approaching.Bao was the first place that we went to after dropping our bags off at our hotel.  As we approached, we noticed a line that we ended up waiting in, until a Bao staffer came out and personally invited us into the place.  We were lucky enough to sit at the bar.  The two bartenders were straight business.  There wasn't much dialogue between them, instead they were focused on executing very intricate beverages.  We ordered the peanut milk, which come in a little bowl.  The flavour of peanuts hits you right away, and the texture was so smooth and velvety.  We ordered three bao each.  The first was the classic, with peanut powder, fermented greens and pork shoulder.  Each element in the pillowy bun balanced out the whole dish beautifully. My only complaint was I wish there were more of the fermented greens.  The second was the fried chicken bao.  This one had far more texture than the first.  I liked how there weren't any crazy ingredients to out shine the super crispy chicken.  The last was the fried bao with ice cream.  This was super neutral and clean.  I think one more element really would have put this over the top, either something fruity or something with some texture.  Overall, we will always remember the amazing flavours that danced across our palette in the first restaurant that we visited in London.

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. eagerly waiting in line for food
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. fried chicken
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. The original

TudUD_jVmfHYj-9xv2etpg.text: Alright. You going to have to lineup but it's definitely worth it. This was one of the most delicious lunches I have had in London. Grab yourself a coffee/beer/champagne piccolo and lineup properly- make it part of your bao experience. When you get a table (yay!) you order from a cute Taiwanese style 'fill in the number' menu. Be hungry and order as much as you can if not everything. They will tell you which ones you need to order '1 per person' of. The space is teenie tiny so eat in pairs or three max or you probably won't fit. It's light and it has maxed out on space utilisation.On the menu you have 4 types of bao; classic (with a nice dusting of peanuts), confit pork (melt in your mouth pork belly), lamb (wow), fried chicken (which is more like a small slider).  and an icecream bao. You also have lots of delicious starters and sides. There are the most amazing mushrooms, peppery scallops, pig's blood pudding with an egg, trotter nuggets, an aubergine dip Taiwan style, fried chicken, beef and guinea fowl rice. Then there are sides of calvero nero with salted egg, pickles like you have never had them before and sweet potato chips. If I were to chose something to recommend then I would say all of it. The bao is soft and fluffy. There is a great spice through all of the dishes and there is a nice balance of fried and veg, soft and crunchy. All of the staff are great. The drinks list looks good. I'd start lining now...

Re0I9QwQ9NY7-MetsYiBeg.text: This place is really to die for!!! We waited in line 45 minutes in the cold to get in and it was really worth it!! The dishes are tasty and different! The service is kind and efficient. We will be back soon!!

zf_AZ8_IPFtDXa4ru76DAA.text: Bao is amazing, both the classic and confit were spot on. Food is unbeatable. Great vibe, very small restaurant. Worth the wait

n3Yf8u8isrP2LxlNXadbIQ.text: Tasty, tasty food .. I didn't know I liked steamed buns until I went here! Friendly service, nice space .. Expect to queue! The highlights for me were the deep fried chicken bites as well as the pork belly bao.

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Pork belly bao

NKELiBViHmRH-jqpKvhotw.text: I, or rather we, knew there was definitely going to be a queue. So the plan was to set   the maximum waiting time and discuss coming up with a contingency plan. In the first 45 minutes we did not move at all. Then just as we debated whether to leave or not, the queue moved and we edged forward a teeny weeny bit. It was both encouraging and frustrating at the same time. Do we leave now or should we stay on? So, as you might gather, BAO does not take reservations. BAO has only 30 seats - all very cosy. Even the tables and chairs are mini size but were luckily, quite comfortable; a few stools around the bar, a couple by the window (one which we frantically prayed we never seated at because you are only a glass window away from the queuers. Hence, eye level when seating is the bum level of the queuer. But we were a company of trio so we were safe, phew!) and a few tables closer to the kitchen. The menu? BAOs were the star of the show but there are plenty of side dishes for nibbles; with the exception my fried chicken; it is a strictly no sharing dish for me. We ordered almost the whole menu except for the soup, scallop, pickles and the fried chicken bun. The dishes are small portions and were served as and when they were ready. There are quite a number of tea, beer and cider choices. No wine. Few non-alcoholic (I find) interesting beverages are foam teas and peanut milk.I love BAO in everyway. The entrepreneurs themselves are laudable. Growing from a humble beginning in the street food scene until a permanent location in Soho with queues that every restaurant craves for, they are a trio that still are as down to earth as any soil. When we left, an hour and a half later, there was still a queue.

50jB4lnQhxWyh3hNntW8UA.text: I went around 3pm and there was no wait. I was immediately seated. The guy next to me recommended the scallops and I'm glad I ordered them. It was delicious. I had the classic and the chicken bao. I liked the classic slightly better. Also, I got pineapple drink (forgot the name). The foam on top was tasty. Overall, service and the food were great.

AJ70zubkk9a7HNL66H48Fg.text: Horrible experienceBeen standing in the cold 30 minuts before opening and no one told me i need to que across even though there were 5 waitors inside chitchatting. Had to go to the end of the que even though i was the first one. The interesting part was that the waitors dont even know what they are serving. I have ordered one each for every bao and apparently the waitor served me classic bao twice and said that this is confit bao, which thankfully i did know it isnt because i have checked the pictures thanks to yelp. She was keep on saying that it is confit and had to call another waitor to prove it is not Food is cold and below standard, very slow on serving foods.

YuwkZGf9ybkZ34Hy3JZqlA.text: I absolutely adore Taiwanese steamed buns and this place doesn't disappoint.  No need to waste your time on anything other than the original.  The others are ok, but merely a distraction from the main event.  The other thing this place has is a dessert bao with ice cream in the middle of what is almost a chewy doughnut on the outside.  It's simply outstanding.  The first time I went we ordered one of everything and the second time we only got classic bao and the dessert bao.  Also, make sure you arrive early because there is no queue if you can be around 15 minutes before they open.  It's a small shop with super fast service, but you'll have to wait if you're not prompt.

ycAgiXwyRHNJMAo5w76uzw.text: Completely full on a Tuesday night and we queued up for around 15 minutes before we got a table. What we ordered: Fried chicken bao: loved the bun and the flavours. Scallops: just one piece and wouldn't order this again. Not great. Taiwanese chicken with ketchup: just regular fried chicken with ketchup over it. Wouldn't order it again. Horlicks ice cream bao: loved this. Soft bun and amazing ice creamTaiwanese whiskey: delicious. Must try Peanut milk: tasted like snickers chocolate and I could have finished a whole bottle of this. SOO GOOD!!! Would go back for the sweet stuff for sure. Cute place but could do with more of a variety. Excellent service.

Ef63AEpF7drkiZiXG7jpIg.text: The baos are totally average... but maybe this is how all the Chinese food is  in London... You can honestly get way better ones in any Chinese cities. It is kinda overpriced for baos, but judging by the prices in London. it's okay. It is a more of a for foreigner/ westerner kinda place. I guess Chinese also go there because there's just not much choices of Asian food in London. Additionally, I just really can't stand the queue for such ordinary boas.

V_4at3fjPwmXFBxGTA1zHg.text: I have seen the crazy looking queues for this restaurant and always thought to myself "ppfffttt you won't catch me queuing for some damn food" .......HOWEVER, last night I put my pride all the way to the side and decided to finally see what the fuss was all about!It hadn't reopened yet for the dinner service but there were people still waiting! Yup! I joined them!I was let in and it was very straight forward.. Sit down and write the quantity of each item you desire...short but sweet menu! I had the fried chicken Bao and the Guinea fowl chi shiang rice to begin with! HOW DO THEY PACK SO MUCH FLAVOUR IN SUCH MINISCULE THINGS!!?!? They were positively delicious! I also had some rose and honey tea which made me feel like the emperor of China!I was about to ask for the bill when I saw the words ... "FRIED HOLLICKS ICE CREAM" ..... Not even the Black Plague could've made me leave after that! I ordered it of course and it was deliciously sinful! The donut in my opinion could be a tad bit softer but the ice cream is to dieeeeeeeee for! Only criticism... The portions are a little too small in my opinion. I'm not a greedy guts or anything but if I pay £5 for a chicken bun I want it to be at least bigger than my toe! And nothing there was bigger than that toe and NOOOO I don't have a massive toe either ..So one could argue the value for money point ... All together I paid £19 for the three plates and tea.. It's an experience so if you want something different go there! But if you want to eat well for under £20 ..not the place.

Vy7-XCMLUHhvCQc6eRxCcQ.text: Open in April 2015,  Bao is one of the new trendy 'it' places to go in London. Queues start at the opposite side of the road and lasts for around 30 mins.Inside it is toasty and cosy with basic ikea style furniture. The menu selection is pretty small - around 15 items to choose from. The waitress recommended we have 2 bao's each (a sort of Chinese burger)  and 10 other items to share between the 4 of us. We ended up ordering 2 bao's each and 7 items to share between us which was plenty!The items we ordered were a bit hit and miss (hence the 4 stars). The chicken bao was crazy delicious but the pork bao was too fatty and the lamb bao was just ok. From the shared items: again the Taiwanese chicken was delicious as was the scallops in yellow bean garlic, but the aubergine won ton was way too salty and the beef soup disappointingly unbeefy.Prices per dish range from 3-5 pounds, but they are small and add up quickly. Service was helpful and friendly even though it was rammed pack. Overall I'm glad we went but wouldn't do the 30 minute queue again!

j5qBiIqLkAi7VYiIBEuMNw.text: Expect to queue! Went on a Thursday at around 7pm and had to wait 30-40minutes for 2. Totally worth the wait. More on the pricer side for Bao but such a cute aesthetic and cozy date spot. Servers were so kind. Pork belly and the ice cream are favs!

gF25wAJ15TsqZchP2cQ78w.text: This is probably by favourite restaurant in London. No, actually it is my favourite restaurant in London. You never want the mouthful to end. From cocktails to dessert, I'd eat here everyday if I could. It's baomazing.

XZHnEcY0nKmmT05SrigYEg.text: 3.5 stars for food2 stars for priceThe baos are good, but I wouldn't go back and pay such a high price for such small portions after having waited in such a long queue. Even my tea was served in a tiny vessel - for two pounds I would expect more than a few sips.

PBWVsk2P-WEPyX-C5uQUWA.text: Great Taiwanese snacks! Got the confit duck & fried chicken bao, pig blood cake, trotter nuggets! All super delicious!! Perfect location and place to some for a break from walking or shopping

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Pork confit bao

vGAZ0mXa8wn_75SVg_D2KA.text: The food here is DELICIOUS. The super friendly staff sat me and didn't peep even if I said I was still waiting for a friend (and that friend turned out to be 15 minutes late), if you know how busy this place gets you'd know why this is a big deal. It was lunchtime and it was packed, and I hear if you come here at dinner you're very likely to find a queue outside the door. The place is extremely small, they've managed to cramp together a few tables so they might fit at least 15 people. Some of the seating spaces are around the bar, and at the end of the room there's the hole in the wall from which you can spy on the kitchen. I ordered a classic bao bun (they suggest at least three per head but...diet), one of their rump steak small plates (my favourite thing so far, even though it's probably no more than 50g of beef) and the mushroom and egg thing. Of which I forget the name. My friend also ordered the aubergine with the wonton fries and it was indeed tasty. One thing that really threw me off (but that's me) is that you could see they were washing glasses and they were LEAVING THEM OUT TO DRY WHEN THEY WERE STILL SOAPY. I do not understand why people in the UK do this. WHY PEOPLE, WHY U NO RINS?Anyway, I think it's super weird but they're not the only ones so not worth taking down another star for that. The one missing is merely because of how tiny the space is, and I do like a bit of space besides my elbows when I eat. Also, the portions are a lot tinier than what they seem on the pictures. Amazingly tasty though, will definitely go back.

s4Lg4I7DgqKBJnIbPNWqTQ.text: Wow. Simply great. We tried all the Baos, here's our ranking: 1) classic 2) fried chicken 3) pork belly 4) diakin 5) lamb (feel free to skip). Ice cream bao is also great. Starters are great too. Just have the whole menu.

0sDFSd-ImSq4tOIreJ6URA.text: Thanks to reading other reviews I knew to stand in line across the street and to arrive before they opened. I arrived a little after 11. The sign was placed across the street for lunch at about 11:30 - first in line! For the next 30 minutes I watched as the line grew behind me starting to wrap around the corner. Unlike another restaurant I recently posted about, this one is worth the wait!Beef Soup, Braised Daikon - Light, refreshing, hot! Great flavor for such a basic broth.Classic - not a fan of the peanut flavor, but that's just personal preference; otherwise very good.Lamb Shoulder - my favorite; loved the spiciness from the jalapenoFried Horlicks Ice cream - wasn't quite sure how to tackle it, but still very goodSweet Potato Chips - that plum pickle ketchup was unexpectedly good

TAlu7EiJDWD-rqqgWJB8Mg.text: I am seriously obsessed with Baos! I just want to eat all the Baos in the world, so when i found out about this special place i knew i had to try it. But apparently i wasnt the only one. I already knew this place is always crazy busy with loooong queues... Eventually decided to give it a go as was finishing work relatively early, or lets say on time! Got there for 6pm.... Still too late, an hours queue on the other side of the road.... But we waited... Patiently... Ohhh, it was worth it! Awesome menu - a selection of 5 savoury baos & lots of little sides. Wonderful - the baos were great - we tried them all (except the veggie one!). Couldnt pick a favourite to be honest, porks are classics but chicken was surprisingly good and of course the lamb! Actually one dissapointment (aside the queue!) The ice cream bao. Really nothing interesting, super ordinary. Basically ice cream with a bun! Would have prefered anothet chicken bao :)Wonderful choice of sides as well - check out the photos to see what we tried, all wonderful! Couldnt pick a favourite either. Ive got to go back to have some more of the same and try the rest of the starters... But need to figure out whens the best time to go and not queue, im assuming weekend late afternoon... I dont know but i need more bao in my life! Side note to the staff - all particularly smiley and friendly!!!

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Finally, ice cream bao. Dissapointing. Nothing special.

rL5uzsUogrOm9RJE15yiRg.text: Incredibly overpriced. The portions are so small that after spending £20 per person we were all still hungry and had to eat again at home. I can't believe we had to queue for 40 minutes for this overhyped and overpriced food.

4E99hNVMK-M101zS-7Ktcw.text: The classic buns are delicious! I would recommend getting that and the fried chicken! I really enjoyed the food here but I didn't rate this as high cause for the price the portions are quite small.

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom

13BnTYQpDXjWINEgKJq0Fw.text: The best restaurant we ate at during our visit to London! Do not miss the opportunity to go here!!!

8_kjHGG3ijev5cb8jaGjoQ.text: You would think that with such a long line, that the food would be amazing. On the night we went, the line was pretty long, so we ended up waiting about 45 minutes. They were nice and brought out hot tea for the people waiting in line. There is limited seating so we had to all squeeze in. The food was good, but pretty expensive for what you got. I would say that you're better off going to Chinatown for value and taste.

5NiRcP66XlZopxTNIGuznQ.text: If you go, be prepared for good food, but be prepared to queue for a while (45 minutes minimum).The line starts across from Bao (in front of the Pret a manger type restaurant's window).  Don't be deceived if you think "oh there's no line" because you are looking at the Bao door.  You will be turned away and the folks across the street who have been waiting there will give you guarded watch.If you go at 10 minutes to closing, you may queue for less time, but that's a gamble.  I arrived at 5:15 pm on a weekday the first time, and waited about 40 minutes.  I arrived at 2pm on a Sunday, and waited about 45 minutes.The food is delicious.  We ordered 5-6 bao (pork belly, lamb, and original are my favs), a peanut milk (yummy), sweet potato fries, 2 ice creams, and I think one other thing for about GBP 55 for 2 folks.  It does take a bit to get the food out - but great unique concept and good flavors.  The staff is extremely friendly - the first time we waited in the rain and the host manning the queue offered us umbrellas.

qfpwMIy2L-HECTFEXO9xjw.text: Loveeee it. The buns are so soft and the fillings are great! There isn't a huge amount of choice of fillings, but definitely enough to suit most people especially as they are alllll so tasty. The buns are very little so you need at least 2 each I would say. The only thing I didn't like was the peanut crumb on my pork bao. It was sugary sweet which I don't enjoy with savoury. I would order it without that next time.

FhBbaaD7_dOzpkXNKV_jVA.text: Sometimes simplicity is best. Bao has an a la carte menu that contains not more than 20 items in total. This is why every single item is so delicious! I tried the scallop, trotter nuggets, Taiwanese fried chicken, fried chicken bao, and fried Horlicks ice cream bao. The ice cream bao is to die for! I would recommend to order a bao for yourself and share some appetisers with friends. The restaurant is quite small but they turnover quite fast. We came here for dinner on a Saturday night and ended up waiting in queue (which is across the street from the restaurant) for only about 20 min. Overall, highly recommended for all the bao lovers out there!

p1HRyAGnxEsFhSyuIh00kQ.text: I had attempted going to Bao about 4 times, before I decided to try one last time before giving up. Yes, Bao is that popular right now! If you want to get a seat within 10 minutes of waiting, instead of 1 hour +, you should get there on a weekday before 11am. That's guaranteed! Ordered all the baos including the Horlicks bao. Amazing!

wAqT3Q6w_EclD-NGL7vjrg.text: I saw photos of the food before coming here and I was really surprised how small the portions were.  I went in around 8 pm on a weekend night and there was a line extending outside.  I thought this place was going to be really good but it is over-hyped.  While each item on the menu isn't necessarily expensive, nothing is filling at all  You have to order multiple to make it a meal and when that adds up, it gets pricey.

Gdtf544wNRFifsG1kityog.text: Bao exemplifies the saying: 'Good things come in tiny packages.'  At around lunch time, there was a significant queue - partially because their Soho storefront just opened, partially because the restaurant only has a few tables and the counter, and partially because - well, the food is popular!  Definitely worth the wait.  Although the other dishes and foam tea looked delicious, I only came in for Classic Bao: a soft steamy bun filled with succulent braised pork and mustard greens(?), topped with sweet, salty, nutty peanuts.  The staff is also friendly, and the vibe is trendy.  Really excellent - believe the hype.

58Hxrvsh2HOiPnIXi7K1kw.text: Slightly over hyped but delicious Bao steamed buns. Delicious comforting snacks if you can cope with the queues.

Id6eB0u7NZQ5q-2RVkzQVg.text: Forget the queuing, these are buns worth queuing for. The selection of Thai tapas is as innovative as it gets, sitting at the counter is super cute and their traditional pork bun is cheap and flavoursome.

N_6YfaKNdFyEmDLelxPsRg.text: Really enjoyed the food here, my first time trying this type of food. Came with a friend, we ordered a good amount of food. Had the spicy fried chicken, 2 pork buns, sweet potato crips, pickles, mushrooms and a couple other small dishes. They were unfortunately out of the scallops, which I would have loved to try. Overall, the food was very tasty and the portions were fairly large for a tapas style meal. The restaurant itself is very small, and we came at 9pm on a Monday and still had to wait 20 minutes. Not sure if they take reservations or not, may be something to look into.

Elt0F8k1AssBxXQ0CEMntg.text: I had been to the stand before and the restaurant was even better. All the Baos were good, with each one having a unique flavour. The tritip cap with white soy was my favourite, but all the small dishes we tried were good to outstanding.

-kXFwfy9jzoBwDbh0eHULQ.text: I loved their stall at Netil Market so was very excited to see them launch a restaurant. I l went on a Tuesday night with my sister. We waited about 40 mins. It's a simple and delicious menu! I really recommend the classic bao and the rump steak. Everything we had was delicious however these were the stand out dishes for me! The service was good, the space is small and simple. I will definitely be back!

JGd7XlqJ5Wqq48XQZ5OQNw.text: Was looking forward to eating here while in town. Tried to get in 30 minutes before closing but was turned away and advised I should have arrived 45 min prior to closing.

g_8mkptBkK-K6fObtoe2jQ.text: It was a very enjoyable meal, every dish were executed wonderfully with not a single bad one in sight. Price is a little more expensive than its street days but that is as expected in a premium location in Soho when the rent can be absolutely outrageous. To sum it up, Bao is all about bringing classic Taiwanese and Cantonese street food elements to London using fine ingredients, recipes that have been popular in the Far East for decades but presented in a modern era.

SjFfoowd1ZVh2CXVl9TFOg.text: Above my expectation as an Asian fusion restaurant judging on the food. Special and partly traditional, partly creative. Waited for almost an hour for lunch on Saturday though. Average service. But if you're looking for a comfy place, this might not be your choice due to narrow space and uncomfortable seating.

E3R9Y2ORuv4Cdac1NRgqnQ.text: Mr Yelp London himself spoke of this place to me, I did;t know that they'd opened their own proper sit down place, so we gladly headed down. Since then, I've been there twice. As with I think, any other place on Lexington street particularly, in the heart of soho, they don't take reservations, (see: Mildreds, oh yes) it's tiny (even complete with a caravan style toilet) and amazingly delicious, do expect a queue. But, it's worth it, annnnd, if the queue is long, they're happy to serve you bottled drinks whilst you're stood there, which tends to keep people happy, and knowing that you get to stick your face in tasty buns at the end, makes it all worth it. When I say this place is small, it's not me being bitchy because I was born out of london in suburbia with sprawling countryside and big, grand old pubs, i mean it, shared tables, and bag hooks above you on the walls to save as much space as humanly possible. You quickly realise that you're sharing your personal space with other people, but it's pretty quick to get used to when you can smell the food...Paper menu, with little pencils, tick off what you want, sometimes there super efficient and hand this to you in the queue, if you're hungry, it's worth doing. Now you're sharing your safe-space radius, prepare to share your food, you don't have to, but I would recommend it, you want to try as many things you can off the menu. In the three times I've been there, I've tried:Trotter nuggets, *****Pigs blood cake, ****Fried chicken (this is very hot sauce, so you know),***Rump cap, ****Scallop, *****Aubergine wontons, ****Confit pork Bao, ****Sweet potato chips ****Daikon Bao, ****Lamb Bao, *****FRIED HORLYCKS ICE CREAM BAO *********With the ice cream, the bao is deep fried, hot and crispy, and the scoop of ice-cream inside, you are going to get sticky, the ice cream is going to try and jump out like those weird jelly sausage thinks you played with as a kid, just get in there, then lick your fingers afterwards. So good.They do run out of things, obviously the earlier you go, the less likely you'll have to queue or miss out on your faves. It's cheapish, definitely worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom

5tMm-Txrs9i9inXLvOXobA.text: We chose to eat at Bao following it's rave reviews on both yelp and the Michelin guide. The wait was approximately 10 minutes, although that could be owing to the fact that it was 5:30pm. The restaurant itself is small, however, Bao manages to emanate a cosy non-claustrophobic vibe. I got the daikon Bao and was pleasantly surprised by the crispy crumbed daikon, which complimented the hot sauce and coriander very nicely. Being of part Taiwanese ethnicity, I am happy to note that the bun does in fact remind me of the traditional ones you find in Taiwan. However, those craving the  authentic peanut sugar may be hard pressed to find it. Only the classic bao comes with it, although the staff were more than happy to accommodate and give me some anyway! The serving size may be a little on the small side, though with the taste being that good and you being in LONDON, I say it is not bad at all. I highly recommend this place. Irrespective of whether you are a Taiwanese craving a taste of home, or just a keen foodie, Bao will deliver. FYI: They also sell cute bags too.

Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Daikon Bao - so good I forgot to take a photo before eating it
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Description of the Menu

cQbwsTcpk470t4fH5WESwA.text: This place is so good. A bit pricey unfortunately, but worth it. The first time I came to this place, the queue was an hour long at 7 on a Friday night. I wasn't expecting this, but I guess I should have. I decided to come back another time, and came when it opened for dinner. Still had to queue about 30 min, but much for bearable. I ate the classic and confit pork bao, had the 40 day rump cap, the Horlicks bao, and peanut milk (which is tiny. Smaller than the small glasses they give for tap water). That was just over £20. The food was incredibly delicious, but small in serving size. I was full after that, however. I came back the next week with my bf and we ordered the Guinea fowl rice, chicken bao, and Taiwanese fried chicken in addition to some of the above mentioned items. They were all excellent as always. The restaurant itself is small and constantly busy, but the staff is quick, helpful, and cheerful.Anyway, long story short, lots of queueing and expensive, but definitely worth it. Try it once and see if you end up coming back.

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom

iJfZ3zHQB6mehpnpWOKQrg.text: When compiling a list of places to eat for a visit in London, BAO came up on my radar though Buzzfeed as a tasty place that had affordable dishes (though can quickly get pricy as you order a number of things since sizes are small). There's a queue that starts across the street. I went around 6-7pm and it was a good 45 min wait so maybe grab a pint at the pub on the same block to drink while in line. Was the food worth the wait? Yes. Is it worth the wait and price? Maybe once awhile. The Pork Bao and Scallops were stand-outs for me. Ambience was easygoing and service was great. The owner sometimes comes out to chat with people. Worth a visit if you can find a time where there isn't a huge queue and you're in the move for some bao.

WzaXdqeT3zFf5gtyW2u19Q.text: I meant to try this place last time I was in London, but the wait was a bit crazy.This time I came for lunch and was lucky that there wasn't any wait.They keep menu pretty simple, but everything on there is good.You come here for the bao (steamed bun with meat filling). We tried 3 of them:-pork, lamb, fried chickenthey also have a daikon, classic and ice cream!I liked the lamb and fried chicken... wasn't crazy about the pork. The service was quick and attentive. If you can avoid the long wait, this place is def. worth it. Can't comment on the price because I find everything in london to be too expensive!

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom

xKg5hh_OyHbhS8IjdXsbaw.text: Walked past here when it was closed and made a note to self, this looks interesting. I was drawn by the image of a man stuffing a Bao in his mouth and I liked the illustration. One night in soho, we're trying to decide what to have for dinner and I remember Bao and head over there. I walk into the restaurant so happy and excited to see what a cool place this was, only to find out that there are 30 other people excited and waiting in line across the street! But the line moves quickly and we're in and order cocktail (not the best place to order drinks) and start ordering lots of small dishes and baos. The pickles are a must, order two or three of them as you won't want to share, very small, but you'll want more! The baos were just what I had imagined, salty, yummy meat with a soft sweet bun, yum! Totally reminded me of San Francisco's Chairman Mao food truck.

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Rice dish
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Bao
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Baos

hP6ZlGSpLLl13O5Msr_-cQ.text: Bao really had me trying hard. First I arrived at 1530 to find out about their break from 1500 to 1730, then I bounces of the door on a Sunday. Today, having done my due dilligence (incl waiting half an hour in a queue) I finally tasted what this place has to offer. As indicated by the rating it was worth the wait. Having tried some od the Bao(lamb and classic, especially the latter is wonderful mixing peanut saltiness with the full body of the meat), the Pig Blood Cake (dont let the name scare you off, it is fatty but tasty), Scallops (bite size), fries(nice twist to it) and the Ice Cream(delicious combo of vanilla ice cream and the toasted bao bun) I can certainly recommend this place. The portions are very small but each one is interesting, distinctive and delicious.

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Vanilla ice cream between toasted bun halves - a must try dessert
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Classic Bao - salty peanut crush wonderfully complimenting the meat

XxP9OjxfX6gaSQzHSsPzPQ.text: 3.5 StarsI don't get the line or the hype. This place's main dish are the baos (braised pork, pork belly, fried chicken, lamb, daikon). Baos are something I see of more as a snack and not a meal.The scallop was a cooked scallop served on a shell, sprinkled with green tea powder and with some minced garlic on top.The aged beef rump cap was some thin slices of beef, slightly cooked but still get pink, marinating in some soy sauce.The fried chicken was round pieces of Taiwanese fried chicken with hot sauce doused on top.The classic bao was pork in shred in a bao (but I don't remember the taste of peanut powder, coriander, or pickled mustard). It tasted mostly of pork and the white bao.The confit pork was also quite porky. Again, I mostly remember the pork and the bun.The lamb shoulder bao had the taste of cumin and lamb, it was actually pretty good.The daikon bao was my least favorite bao. It was a rectangle of shredded daikon deep fried and topped with a single, thin slice of pickled daikon on top. I thought this dish was bland and boring.The horlick ice cream was pretty good. I liked the taste of the ice cream even though it was a bit too soft and runny. The fried dough sandwiching it on top and bottom was tasty but I liked it better eaten apart from the ice cream.Overall, all the food had a pretty good taste but it wasn't very inventive and not even very Taiwanese fusion. If this place had more menu items besides appetizers and baos, that would also make it more interesting.

YxAf8wdp5-UhRiHzUA3aZA.text: It's rare to find a place in London with such good Asian food, so we were happy to have found BAO. Although portions are small, their signature buns are so delicious, especially the one with lamb. If you prefer quality over quantity, this would be the place for you. The only downside is that their cocktails are overpriced (about 8 pounds or 10 dollars) and the taste is not that good.

aCjGCn1Ft1885vVTtm6RgA.text: Personally I wasn't a huge fan of BAO. I went in for lunch after waiting maybe 10 minutes outside. I ordered the guinea fowl rice, a classic bun, and a fried chicken bun. The rice was delicious, definitely the highlight of the meal. The classic and fried chicken buns were just ok. The best part of the classic was the bun which was super fluffy, the filling wasn't anything to write home about and luke warm. The fried chicken could have been much better if it had more flavor, I found it a bit bland.

kZ8qLjRdmtDCQCgosrgk1A.text: This place was not worth the wait... but it was pretty good. Portion was a bit small I recommend some bao, sweet potato fries and fried chicken. Nice little snack not enough for a meal but it was fine because then we went to nandos after.

LTuuuAq-daa5Zh7NyrqdUg.text: This small restaurant is worth queuing for and yes you will be queuing. There's very limited seats inside but the turn around is quite fast. I would recommend to go at lunch and a bit outside the usual 1 - 2pm to avoid the queue.The food is delicious, although the portion are a bit small: we took 2 Bao and 1 side each. I could have eaten more, but I was a bit conscious of the price (between £5-£7 for a bun, that ended up being an expensive lunch).That being said, the food is really worth the money and the wait.Service is great.

Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom

fHZDn64uwrTbmeyYuc4Owg.text: Waited in line for about 30 minutes with a buddy of mine, not too bad for a Saturday. I had the scallop, original bao, chicken bao, porkbelly bao and the horlick bao. Lives up to the hype and would go again.

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Scallop
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Original bao - the best of the bunch!
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Pork belly bao

oeKprOtnb_9pVjDI8-tvOg.text: I'm sorry, I just don't get it.I love bao (the food).  Amazing, really, when they're done right.  But I just don't understand a 30-60 minute wait to eat only "ok" bao for 1.5x the price.  The fried chicken bao is the only exception, but I am starting to see near comparisons for slightly less money and significantly less wait time popping up in places like Ippudo.  Speaking of Ippudo, their bao are (1) bigger, (2) less expensive, and (3) frankly, better.The restaurant does provide some interesting interpretations, with ice cream and sweet bun bao for example, but there is something really unsatisfying in each of their new creations.  They've moved away from rich flavours and small bites to simply small bites of semi-ordinary flavours.  The high mark-up and relatively novelty will certainly keep them in business, but it certainly won't keep me going back.So go once to check it out, because we all know you will, and because it's a cool concept and the line offers an air of exclusivity for those "in the know" - this is why I took a chance!  Unfortunately, however, this place is remarkably similar to Barrafina on Frith St. in one key way: they will get strong reviews because of this air of exclusivity and novelty, but not because what should be real drivers of rating, the quality and quantity of food that you get, in the right ambiance, for the right price.

uNOesOME0Q20kBcP0TBAvA.text: Overall Score: 4Service/Ambiance Rating: 4Food Rating: 4What to say about BAO? They didn't do anything wrong... but they didn't do anything great either. Like some other reviewers, I don't think I understand what the rave is about. For me, the potion sizes are so small that I can't comfortably enjoy my meal... I just keep thinking how many holes are being drilled into my wallet just to keep my stomach full.While I don't think I will return to BAO, I did enjoy their take on dessert with their ice cream bao.

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Notorious wait for BAO

ArW9Mm_wPRcqO55SH7A2Lw.text: Lovely place with some phenomenal baos. The dessert bao with deep fried buns and Horlicks ice cream is definitely not to be missed - and serves my childhood memory of the drink very well. Fun combinations of small plates. Long line, but worth the wait. Come early!

iGrhJvVLj84z0flRoGbsCg.text: Always one of my favourite places in soho! Expect to wait like 20-40 mins. The food here is flavoursome and beautiful to look at. Almost a shame to eat it! I always order the scallops and the classic bao. They are so different and it's like nothing I ever had anywhere else. The food looks small but I always end up stuffed. They recommend to order 3 - 4 dishes and I think that's the right amount. Would cost you roughly £15-18 including service charge. Also be prepared to eat next to a stranger as it's a small place and there's really limited tables.I love the tote bag with the man eating the bao. So clever and a great souvenir for only £5!!The staff are lovely, quick service and very attentive. Amazing place!

nBbuf9Z1VfzdCatyu2bB1Q.text: I LOVE BAO. Totally worth the wait in line. I went really late at night and got in with no wait at all. The tea was excellent even thought there was only 1.5 cups worth. They make it the traditional way where you over pour the tea and let it spill all over the sides. The peanut milk was also very sweet and interesting.  Definitely sweet enough for a desert. I actually wasn't as crazy about the baos as I was the other items on the menu.

I1ShHjiHgxT7mJcKNJkwjw.text: Omg! It is totally worth the wait! It has been a while since I got this foodgasm and although London food scene is very attractive, only few restaurants can hit the right spots.I tried the chicken and the lamb bao and both were flavourful and perfectly balanced. The sweet potatoes fries are a must and the garlicky scallop was a nice spicy touch. I didn't try the iced/fried Horlick ice cream because I was having desserts in an another place but would definitely come back!Nevertheless to say that the team there is efficient and super nice!Super recommended!

CZ6mhknIkusqIsUVXzPGSg.text: Second time at Bao, and we managed to avoid a long queue. Service is always prompt here, and we weren't rushed towards the end of our meal despite it being the peak of lunch hour which was appreciated. The food was good, especially the Horlicks Bao at the end, but nothing out of the world. If you are expecting the quality you would get in parts of Asia, you will be slightly let down. It is also pricey for the small portion sizes. Regardless, it was a decent meal and enough to satisfy any cravings you might have. They also have a good selection of tea.

ATwedeODEyb9-JP9brjZaw.text: This place was delicious but really quite expensive! My boyfriend and I ended up just having a couple orders of bao and eating a more full meal elsewhere.If you're looking to splurge a bit, this would be a great option because the food was quick and yummy!

PeXepM0yETIJJoBPmzI4PQ.text: This place met up to the hype!! As many reviews here claim... the hype is REAL!! Considering we waited in the queue for ~30-45 minutes in the freezing cold, the whole experience was not tarnished (to my surprise). The waiter kindly escorted customers in queue across the street in to the restaurant.  The seating arrangements were extremely packed and tight.  I figured it was all part of the experience (make sure you level your expectations in terms of elbow room lol) We ordered 7 baos (3 for the lady, 4 for the guy), shared Korean fried chicken small plate, had a bottle of beer, and a cup of milk tea.  That was perfect to share for two :) The bao: Classic (you may need at least 2 of these delicious baos) Pork belly (this and Classic are must have's for first-timers) Lamb Fried chicken (you're better off ordering the Korean fried chicken appetizer!) The buns were extremely fluffy and soft. Most buns I've tried end up with a slightly dry skin - but these buns at Bao remained soft even when the baos cooled down.  The meats were flavorful - I especially liked the pork belly with the fried onions (pork belly flavors really came out).  My friend was a huge fan of the classic buns because there was a variety of flavors. I'll admit this place came out more expensive than I expected but I still dream about the baos after returning back to the States.  :')

_X-RHLygHYN8eJfYQ3aPOA.text: Ahhh, I'm conflicted on this one.I applaud Bao for taking a street vendor concept and making Taiwanese food instagrammable, adding modern twists with minimal compromise of authenticity, and their marketing prowess from the logos, the nifty dim-sum style ordering, and beautiful presentation stretches the price point to the edge of reason.  In other words, this is millennial Taiwanese food perfection, whereas the old school parents of the same target demographic would recoil in horror.  Being an Xennial, straddling between GenX and Millenial, I am cursed to see things from both perspectives.    It can appreciate the fact that it is a feast for the eyes but a mere tease for the stomach since even after spending around 40 quid for two, my companion and I were ready to head somewhere else for a complete dinner, and we are usually the type that gets full over one entree and one app split among the both of us.If I were to pick a few items for sampling, the fried chicken bao with the enigmatic black sesame bao and the fried bao w/ Horlicks ice cream are blissful bites, and the pulled pork and lamb buns are a little off the reservation but well executed.  The peanut milk is quite delicious although they are pretty stingy even with the volume on this nonalcoholic beverage (a small teacup's worth)  Perhaps if money and value was not a factor and I'm eating my heart's content on the company dime, there would be a 1 star bump, but knowing one can eat at least double the quantity of equal or better quality at less than half the price in Taiwan, it definitely detracts from the experience no matter how pretty and how innovative one modifies food offerings whose baseline is pretty close to perfection.

htBwNLh5i8Py9pkHMCbZfA.text: Hot diggity buns! Bao's sandwiches really shine but you will pay the price in terms of GBP and time. Thankfully a friend got here early so I didn't have to wait but the line filled up fast at lunch and they didn't seem rushed to get us out for the next customer.Food came fairly quickly once ordered although any drinks will take awhile even if seated at the bar. I had a refreshing milk foam tea which is what it sounds like: oolong tea on ice topped with a thick milky foam that is fun to drink but steep for the small glass at £4.The standout dish was the fried chicken bao. It came with a sesame bun, perfectly cooked chicken and kim chee with sauce. You will drool and you will devour it.The side dishes I enjoyed were the bbq scallop: note you only get one for £3.75 which is overpriced but tasty. The aubergine dip with wonton crisps were yummy and best for sharing although I could have used more crisps. Skip the beef soup with plain daikon, a bit dull. My friend enjoyed the fried daikon bao but not as much as the chicken.Be prepared to pay more for small bites but leave full and happy. Personally I wish they would do take away so I could grab some bao and go.

cDtHW0LtcLwA7g8mnmGluA.text: Delicious, dreamy Taiwanese baos with perfect varieties like pork confit, fried chicken, and ice cream. When we got to BAO around 5 PM, there were already 15 or so people in line in front of us and we ended up waiting around an hour. The interior is very cozy and I often found myself bumping elbows with my friends sitting beside me, which just opened up more opportunities to rave about the food between bites. Yes the menu is small but each item is deliciously made, and worth every second of the wait and more.

mcEe386JB5XkW6GHoj15iQ.text: Listen, the food is amazing. It's five star. But everything else stinks.1. You have to queue up to get in. Across the street. 2. You're paying £5 for bao that are 2-3 bites each. 3. You might as well be sitting on friends' and strangers' laps. 4. Very limited menu. 5. We had a party of 4 that spent over £70, and the first thing we did after leaving was go find a place to eat. So, if you have money to burn and aren't very hungry anyway... this is the place for you.

B3ICj52-cGR2g1l5ixePag.text: This has become a must-visit for me whenever I get to travel to London. I usually dislike these "popular"/"hip" places that have lines, but Bao really delivers. Plus, even if you absolutely hate waiting in line, it's gotten manageable enough recently that on weekdays, my party has always gotten in with the first seating so long as we show up before the noon opening time.As far as the "xiao chi" / small plates, IMO the fried chicken, scallop, and guinea fowl rice are the standouts. My favorite bao are the lamb shoulder and the original, although I find all to be quite good and I often disagree with my dining companions as far as our favorites. And obviously with my sweet tooth, I think it's a requirement that everyone should have the Horlicks dessert bao on every visit.I love that they have Kavalan whisky available too - make sure to give it a try if you haven't!

VjPhVE2QZt-NfgbrXCorTg.text: 3.5 stars. The bao were delicious. I had the classic and the lamb bao. Both were perfectly spiced fun little sandwiches. Expensive for how tiny they are, but really a delicious little bite. The trotter bits were also extremely excellent. Yum!Aubergine with crispy wontons were not very good. I would definitely pass on that one. I would also pass on the milk foam tea. Very bland and boring. Overall a very expensive little lunch, but loved the bao.

wF0Bq__cXKFg-L2vdGqCiA.text: Came to this place for dinner right before 6 so I was able to get a seat right away. People started lining up outside this little shop immediately after. It gets quite busy! There isn't air conditioner in there so it got very hot halfway through my dinner.Pork belly bao (5/5): this is definitely the highlight of this place. the pork was juicy and flavorful.Lamb shoulder bao (4/5): i love lamb but I don't think this bao does it justice. The lamb was not that special, it was good but nothing really stood out.Tea (3/5): I forgot the exact flavor of the tea but I remember it was a flower herbal tea. The tea was not aromatic and it came in a very small tea pot--not quite worth the pricePeanut Milk (3/5): similar to the tea, came in a very very small tea cup and tasted quite average.Tip: Go for the pork belly bun!

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Pork belly Bao

BIgUo89jUayzAp_bAvrrlA.text: This place is delicious - definitely some of the best baos I've ever had in my life. Like the name implies, they specialise in baos, so I'd definitely stick to ordering that vs. trying other things on the menu. I found some of the other dishes to be hit or miss, but loved all the baos. Moral of the story is don't diversify in food selection - just get 3-4 of the baos and you'll be a happy camper. Your wallet will also be happier.First, the place is tiny so be prepared to wait in line, across the street from the restaurant. Don't come with a party greater than 2-3 people because you won't fit -- maybe max of 4 people, but it will be harder to get a table. I came at 1 pm on a weekday and had to wait about 15-20 minutes.Baos: I tried 2 of them, the classic pork and the pork confit (pork belly). Both were fabulous, but I liked the classic one the best because of the peanut powder on top. The pork belly was also really delicious and I loved the dried shallots on top - the pork belly meat wasn't overly fatty and it was really good. My friend had 4 of the baos and he liked them in this order (best to worst): classic pork, daikon, pork confit, lamb. The bread of the baos are the best, fluffy and soft so it feels like you are biting into The other dishes were fine, they were not terribly memorable to me. The scallop was good, but not £3.75 good, for just one piece of scallop. I liked the fried chicken pieces but to be honest, I've had other fried chicken that is better, so I'd rather just save my stomach room for the baos. We also got the guinea fowl rice which had a perfectly runny yolk, fried shallots, and pork, and it was good but nothing quite to write home about. The biggest disappointment was the special that was roasted shrimp with green onions. We were told what the special was, but failed to confirm that it was a bao. To our disappointment, it was not. It was a bowl of tiny shrimp that you had to peel each one individually. For £6 per bowl, it felt like such a waste of money, stomach space and time. We thought someone was pranking us and laughing at us in the back, watching us peeling tiny shrimp. My friend said the shrimp was the right size if you were a mouse. Needless to say, if this is the special, skip it. I had the fried bao with ice cream for dessert but didn't think this was anything super special. It was like eating a cold donut shaped like a bao with a scoop of ice cream inside. The ice cream was kind of a sweet milk flavor, and it was good. I love sweet things over savory but would have rather had one of the savory baos instead. In short, come here, with only 1 or 2 other people, expect to wait about 30 min or so for lunch, and get only the baos. Get all of the flavors that they offer for baos - they are all so different and delicious. It's not cheap though, my half of the meal for lunch ended up being about £30 ($42 USD). I'd definitely come back here again though!

swlpI5-GIj53LynrVXmkWg.text: Loved this little bao house in Soho. If you're the claustrophobic type you may want to check out the other location. I, however, loved sitting at the bar. The small format space reminded me of being in Tokyo and who doesn't want to be reminded of being in Tokyo?Also, being at the bar facilitated my ordering of drinks. I ordered a few of the bao including pork belly, lamb and fried chicken. They were pretty delicious and succulent. A bit on the pricey side for bao, but on the other hand that didn't deter me. Food quality was top notch, service was excellent, and the vibe was buzzy without being obnoxious. I also appreciated how the staff managed the queue to ensure diners inside weren't rushed or pressured while outside people queued up in an orderly fashion with an overwhelming and palpable sense of longing that made being on the inside feel so awesome!

JCy98rSkpqGITsYefJbK4w.text: I stayed around the corner from this place when I visited London & popped in for a solo lunch in the afternoon, and oh man, was it good! I was sat right away at the counter, given a menu & explained how their restaurant worked. I ordered some baos, fried chicken, and their pickles.The food was AMAZING - the fried chicken is a must get. I was so happy with it and could of eaten atleast 2-3 more platefuls of that. The bao was pretty good as well, I got the pork belly and it was a good mixture of salty, sweet & light.Only thing was the price was expensive, but hey, its SoHo and I was on vacation!Definitely try to go for lunch if you can -- you'll have little to no wait! I walked by one evening after eating and saw the line across the street. That's commitment!

DlNyfjqGjmuaMCyVNRJKNQ.text: Let's start with... the line is across the street. Not sure why they don't put a sign out so that they don't have patrons going in and asking for a table only to be told there is a long line across the street.I went around 2:30, to avoid the lunch rush but still ended up waiting about 30 minutes.I tried all of the baos expect the vegetarian one with Daikon. The best one I'd have to say is the fried chicken with the kimchi. However, I would not say that the baos here are that amazing, generally speaking. Its a cool idea, serving it in different styles, but in all honesty, I really like the baos I've had in a traditional Taiwanese restaurant and wouldn't necessarily go out of my way and stand in a long line to get a bao here. Also, my favourite dish is not even a bao, but the black pudding with the egg yolk on top, so rich so delicious. The sweet potato fries were good, I would call them sweet potato served tempura style.

1pztdw0ph_nba4JxmkrXXQ.text: I was very scared walking up to Bao because there were so many large crowds outside, but I wouldn't totally despair at this sight since a lot of the people are drinking outside the bars nearby and in line for neighboring restaurants. Given the crowds, it's also difficult to know where to queue; I talked to one of the servers inside and she led me to the end of the line, about 8 people/3 parties long, across the street. They also give you a small discounted drink menu that is exclusive for while one is waiting in line, which I thought was a good idea to keep diners engaged and high-spirited. Since all the drinks are just £3 on this special menu, the spiked soda is the best deal. It tasted like generic red flavor and whatever alcohol was in there was not strong, but it was refreshing. My friend and I waited around 25 minutes total, not at all a long time when there is a lot of catching up and chatting to do! The menu is short and simple, which I appreciate. My Taiwanese friend back home said that the classic pork and lamb shoulder were a must, so I ordered those two along with the pork confit bao. My friend and I shared the fried chicken and trotter (pork) nuggets as well. The food came out swiftly. The classic pork was my favorite for its peanut crumb topping. I also liked the tender fried chicken pieces with its coarse crunchy breading. Since it's a small restaurant with tables very close to one another, it gets quite loud inside. Even though Bao is clearly very popular, there are no elite attitudes or egos--the staff are very friendly! The wait time was not ridiculous on a Thursday evening, and the whole process is smooth since they clearly have their operations down.

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Bottom to top: Fried chicken and trotter (pork) nuggets

The lamb was good too but a decent amount below the other two, in my opinion.Not the cheapest lunch option and not my absolute favorite bao of all-time, but very solid all around.

9HVkjK76vG9RE4zQsXIH7g.text: This place is worth checking out even though the wait time is ridiculous.  Just have an early dinner or a really late lunch.The lamb shoulder bao, pork confit, and daikon tasted great.  The lamb shoulder was my favorite, that I ordered a second.

yArwktha4Ufq92hk92iW2w.text: Back again and we knew what we wanted - 1 lamb bao each! But then felt after waiting a whole 5-10min we should aim to get more so also ordered the mapo eggplant rice bowl (btw, mapo eggplant! excellent idea! why has is this not everywhere?) and the fried horlicks bao for dessert.The lamb bao were awesome.The mapo eggplant was okay-good. The sauce was really good. Some of the eggplant wasn't cooked all the way through and was still a little hard. I would have liked more mapo sauce. I think you need to mix the sauce into the eggplant before eating, otherwise the eggplant can be bland. The fried horlicks bao was okay-good. If you like horlicks or are nostalgic for horlicks you'll like it more than an American like me.If you come with 2 people you'll be seated pretty quickly even with the line. More than that and you'll have a noticeably longer wait.
