OuytD-fTe0SBPikofEpHfw.text: Inventive Asian destination with small plates / dim sum feeling.  What I loved was how each dish was creative and flavorful - you could eat forever at this place.  The vibe was inviting but hip.I found the servers less inviting, and the quality of the ingredients substandard for a restaurant at this price point.

BuEtKgFfaC-MLJBINs-okw.text: I went here after reading about their Pork Confit Bao's being a must-try in London, but I think they were overrated. There was a decent amount of pork in the bun, but I would have liked some more to balance out the bun taste. My mom ordered the Fried Chicken Bao, and that was truly delicious! I would definitely go back for those!! There was so much chicken, a delicious sauce and some veggies. The perfect combination!

photos.caption: Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Top: Fried Chicken Bao Bottom: Pork Confit Bao

kxYQoJudh6RaWy2Dnj3SYw.text: This is a long overdue review, as I went there about two years ago!It is a small space, so there will be queues during popular times. BAO was a pioneer in London to expose the city to the namesake food, and they did it well. Creative flavours. That was 2-3 years ago - nowadays, places serving bao have mushroomed across the city, and having eaten at other places, I don't think I would queue for BAO again.The food is executed well, but not that hugely different/higher than what you could get at other bao specialists in London anymore.

apW1vm_w3KJgjBzuK1FKtg.text: Wow. A hidden gem. We did not know what to expect so the 2 of us shared 1 of each of 12 different things that appealed to us. Let me tank order our favorites:1. Classic bao £4.752. Taro White Russian drink £8.53. Guinea fowl chi shiang rice £64. Confit pork bao £55. Beef soup, braised daikon £3,256. Aubergine, wonton crisp £3.757. Taiwanese fried chicken £5.58. Eryngil mushroom, century egg £4.59. Scallop, yellow bean garlic £3.7510. Aged beef rump cap, aged white soy sauce £611. House pickles £212. Mapo aubergine chi shiang rice £6The classic bao is so good because of depth of flavor and textures. Wonderfully balanced savory tender meat with crunchy sweet chopped peanuts wrapped in a fluffy hot white steamed bun or bao. The Taro foam (light purplish) White Russian was sweet without being sickly sweet. This drink has no satiation point. You can keep drinking it and you still want more. Dangerous!There is an £80 tasting menu where they bring you 1 of everything (possibly 21 different items). Excluding drinks. We ordered £55 for 2 of us and that was plenty.

mKNN6_nmGoCXErceaOsuJw.text: Had the classic, Pork Confit and Fried Chicken Bao The pork and Fried chicken was amazing!!   For dessert we had the Fried Horlicks Ice Cream.

gubhB91_NHKPG4N02nNDbw.text: TL;DR: great place if you want to try lots of different flavors in one meal! Slightly expensive for the portion sizes, but fantastic plates. If you're hungry, you will definitely need to order at least two buns (and I mean it) because everything is portioned out for ant-sized people.Our waitress recommended two buns each (upwards of £4.75) and 4-5 sides to share between the two of us. We followed this and it was a perfect amount of food. We tried the classic bao (the best of what we tried), the fried chicken bao, and the confit pork bao. We also ordered the Taiwanese fried chicken, the pickles, the nuggets, house salad, and the two dessert buns.The classic bao was by far our favorite and we will absolutely order again. The fried chicken is a must try as well, while everything else was good but not overwhelmingly delicious. The ice cream dessert buns were more of a donut texture but very yummy after lots of savory foods. Worth trying if you love bao buns and want a delicious meal. However, not sure it'd be worth the 30+ minute queue which can build up outside.Drinks wise: we only got the milky tea which was iced green tea topped with a whipped cream. Really refreshing!

26u9j2bB9lHt5wV0t6A3Mg.text: We had to queue across the street and have people gawk at us from the fishbowl, but this was one of the best meals we had in London!---- APPETISERS ----Beef Soup Braised Daikon:  4.5 stars£3 for a small bowl but flavourful, hearty, spicy beef broth like Korean kalbi stock.Guinea Fowl Chi Shiang Rice:  3.5 stars---- BAOS ----Classic:  5 starsThe bun is irreproachable, the meat is complex and also perfect.  The sweet peanut powder on the pork is an incredible touch.Lamb Shoulder:  5 starsSpicy Indian curry sauce.Confit Pork:  4.5 starsFried Chicken:  3.5 stars---- TEA ----Oriental Beauty Tea:  5 starsServed in a 160ml Yixing teapot. D0gu-1zWWvOiMOeBiVnMGw.text: I am Gua Bao crazy.Crazy for Taiwanese steamed buns.Soft, fluffy buns filled with mouthwatering ingredients.This is BAO.While in London last year, I made a beeline for BAO, an upmarket Taiwanese eatery located in the Soho area.The restaurant is small, yet cosy and staff are friendly and efficient. BAO doesn't take bookings, instead you have to wait in line... at a designated spot across the street, in front of a man eating bao. (Laughs).When I arrived for lunch on a weekday, the place was packed. Luckily, the service is quick (without the feeling of being rushed), so I ended up waiting in line for only 10 minutes.But, waiting in line for their bao is worth it.Their menu is simple. It consists of Taiwanese small plates - 9 dishes, 5 bao, 4 sides and one dessert bao. When ordering, you simply tick the box next to the dish you want and then hand it over to the wait staff.While I wanted to order all 19 dishes, I only ordered three - the Classic Pork Bao and Taiwanese fried chicken, and for dessert, the Fried Horlicks Ice Cream Bao.The Classic Pork Bao was perfect - a fluffy pillow-like bun of goodness, filled with pulled pork, fermented peanut powder and coriander. Melt in your mouth!The Taiwanese Fried Chicken with hot sauce was also very good - finger licking good. Crispy on the outside, tender on the inside.But my favourite dish was definitely the Fried Horlicks Ice Cream Bao - a must order when dining at BAO. It is a scoop of creamy malt ice cream between two sweet buns. Simple, but done well. Plus, it looks super cute!As of last year, I had not seen a dessert bao on an Auckland menu. Now you can get them at Auckland eatery Po'Brothers. Yay!BAO is the creme de la creme of bao. I would highly recommend eating here if you are in London. I cannot wait to go back, just so I can try more of BAO's creations!

huqRKC_lj_9ezZscIP5qww.text: This place is to die for... (which we almost did waiting an hour in line in the cold...!)Normally I would not have the patience to wait in line, but I really wanted to try this place.  I even came back a second time to see if the line was shorter alas it was not.BAO has managed to create a fun tapas style dining experience that allows for you to try many different dishes.  The flavors that the chef imparts in these dishes are truly a work of art.  If you want to take your taste buds on a culinary journey then I'd highly advise you to check this place out!!

cieWTskPsrrVTFAgymIMOQ.text: BAO specializes in delicious and creative... well, you guessed it... baos. One of the best parts of this dish is the bread itself, and this restaurant serves it perfectly fluffy and chewy. The filling comes in a number of flavors. You have your classic pork and chicken, but then you also get interesting ones like daikon and ice cream. To balance out the meal, they offer a variety of small eats to select from the menu.While I love the concept of this restaurant, I don't think their prices are quite justifiable. I get that they can charge a premium, being in the heart of London and all, but the servings are definitely on the smaller side. It really doesn't cost all that much to make a bao either, so the math just doesn't add up for me.XIAO CHI// Scallop, Yellow Bean Garlic (£3.75) - 4 stars// Beef Soup, Braised Daikon (£3.25) - 3 stars// Eryngii Mushroom, Century Egg (£4.50) - 3 stars// Aubergine, Wonton Crisp (£3.75) - 2 stars// Guinea Fowl Chi Shiang Rice (£6) - 4 stars// Taiwanese Fried Chicken, Hot Sauce (£5.50) - 4 starsBAO// Classic (£4.50) - 5 stars// Confit Pork (£5) - 4 stars// Fried Chicken (£5) - 4 stars// Lamb Shoulder (£5) - 4 stars// Fried Horlicks Ice Cream (£4.50) - 4 starsSIDES// Peanut Milk (£2.50) - 3 stars

RzpGvi2q66wHAqD7B1WK3g.text: Firstly, I love this place. I had waited for Bao to open a proper place since discoering it in Netil Market in East London and their little food shack.Taiwanese street food, mainly of Bao bun form was a winner when I had gone to visit the market. Unfortunately like what seemed 100 others I queued up, in the rain, on a Saturday morning for what seemed like an hour. But I wanted to try this food bad. And boy was it worth it.So upon sorting a meet to try the new shop in Soho, I again waited. this time for an hour. It was like Groundhog Day. It's also the main reason why I cannot give this place 5 stars. It has ALWAYS got a queue. Whatever the time of day. Well ok maybe if you go about 2.36pm por something I'm sure it isn't as bad.But let me tell you about the food. There isn't a bad thing on the menu. At all. I loved it. All of it. My favourite being the lamb bao, blood cake with egg and the guinea fowl mix bowl. You could get anything and be happy. Though I heard a murmur that maybe the bao buns might be smaller here.I do love that they are social media happy, which means that they are very open to suggestions and a lot of 'off menu' items. So start mixing items...like putting an egg in a bao, or a blood cake in it, or doing something a bit photo worthy. If you ask nicely of course. And yeah, come as early from work as possible! Either that or bring a bottle of beer for the queue!

nAswnbAmJRXkOw5dIc6tTA.text: Warily eyeing the 40+ person line at 6:30 pm on Saturday, I silently cursed my affinity for instantly joining queues, even if it was to wait for a table at the very popular Bao. As soon as the host came out of the restaurant, I asked him how long the wait would be. He answered, "For one I can probably seat you now!". Sometimes, it pays to be a loner.I immediately went instead and perused the menu. The only bad thing about eating alone is that you can't order everything without looking like a pig, but I have no shame. I ordered the fried chicken bun, the pork belly, and the stewed pork. Out of the three, the fried chicken was the best with its sesame bao, and I wished I ordered another one. The pork belly was also delicious, and the stewed pork was nice but I would want to try something different next time. To top it off, I had the fried milk bun with Horlicks ice cream, and it was heaven. I am definitely coming back, with or without friends.

8MYE_wbqQhsILTeH4KBMDQ.text: The reviews for this place are definitely right... WORTH THE WAIT. We shared and tried the classic, pork, lamb and chicken bao's. My favorite were the classic and the pork. The sweet potato fries with the plum sauce were also very delicious as was the scallop. The only reason I didn't give it the full 5 stars was due to the trotter nuggets, while they didn't taste bad they didn't taste like much except fried food. Other than that food came quick, service was friendly and the food was good!

PNPvXeqMABxaxNuAROcLWA.text: The place is so good and the food is great! Really authentic and very good for dinner/evening  meal with a drink. But not for lunch... Because the food is a bit too salty and it has to go with some beers.

Ldykn91HEtd5jiDTBzp1og.text: The savoury bao is good enough, but the ice cream fried bao is a real pleasure if you're a sweet tooth.

NoLOc9goc-eQHD1P8x_i9w.text: After the much anticipated wait, Bao has finally opened their Soho restaurant!I ordered the peanut milk, which came served with ice in a small glass - it was really tasty and refreshing, and I could have easily downed a couple more glasses.Their menu is divided into three categories: 'Xiao Chi' ("small eats"), Bao, and Sides.The scallop was fresh with fragrant flavours from the yellow bean garlic. I find soup dishes very comforting, and I would highly recommend the beef soup, which seems to be a favourite amongst many who have tried it. The aubergine was really soft and smooth, and it was fun to eat it with the crispy pieces of wonton skin. Their pig blood cake which many had raved about was actually really tasty. After watching multiple videos and 'before and after' shots of that gooey egg yolk, I finally tried it for myself. It had a pleasant texture, and it was really moreish - another favourite from the menu!The trotter nuggets had a light and crisp golden coating with deliciously tender meat inside - so good that I had the whole dish to myself.The guinea fowl chi shiang rice was topped with a bright yellow egg yolk which was great to eat mixed together with the rice.We ordered three different savoury baos - lamb shoulder, confit pork and the fried chicken. I have only ever had their classic bao from their market stall, so it was nice to try a few more variations, all of which I enjoyed. It was hard to choose, but my favourite amongst the three was probably the confit pork bao.And of course I couldn't pass out on dessert which was the Fried Horlicks Ice Cream. It was interesting to see Horlicks being used which was more of a childhood drink for me. It is however not the easiest thing to eat without getting your fingers smothered in melted ice cream...At the end we washed it all down with some foam cold-pressed tea which was really refreshing.The food has definitely lived up to the hype and it is of no surprise that there have been queues of people outside.I will be back for more...Click on my blog link for the full post with photos xdancing-in-high-heels.bl…

d09b7mbAm1zKTGrKI3Ig-A.text: Has anyone played Chubby Bunny Cheeks here? I wouldn't mind if you mistook me for a person who could probably eat enough to qualify as a contestant or thought I was able to confidently enter any sort of competition involving winning a prize for eating whilst reigning triumphant. Bao down to me. Sometimes I can be greedy. Especially if the food is delicious. I'll take you back to summer camp, the mid 90's. I was wearing Hammer pants, an Ace of Base T-Shirt and a waterproof pink and orange neon Le Coq Sportif cagoule. (It was England, so of course there was drizzle). My kinder gang and I had successfully collected enough kindling to get a crackling, cheek roasting, polyester-cagoule melting, roaring fire going. It was at this life transforming event that I was introduced to marshmallows, but not just any marshmallows, these were brought by our exotically tanned American, camp-leader Justin; Prince of all Knots, all the way from the land of Shee-Cahr-Goh. This miraculous bag of giant, child's fist-sized puffy white clouds of powdered sugar were toasted in a fire, where the gelatine emulsified creating globules of sweet crispy toasted candy which dripped down my twig just savagely ripped off a nearby tree, glorious.  Hot strings of melted happiness. The reason I fondly recalled this memory at Bao, was I believe, a survival technique that kicked in. A happy place I went to when, I was served... tiny preschooler-fist-sized scantily filled  steamed rice buns.Back to camp nostalgia. I was thoroughly enjoying the, little did I know, to be revered experience until I recalled when some fool of a child said: "Bet you can't stick 4 of those in your mouth at once". Before I knew it, 8 year old Craig and I were at war. Stuffing our mouths with mallows in a competition of 'Chubby Bunny Cheeks', where the object of the game is to stuff as many marshmallows into your mouth in a game of one-upmanship in speech articulation.  "Tschubby Buhnny Scheeks"! I exalted, stuffing a 8th in to match his 7th. It was his turn next."Kubby Bungy Keeks"! He yelped victoriously.'Kubby Bungy Keeks is not the game", I intensely corrected. "I win".I went in for the kill with the 10th while sugary saliva dried in my hair and dripped down the middle of Ace of Base. I'd won. Justin, supervising, helped me raise my fist-punch into the air triumphantly. However it was to be a bitter sweet victory. We could no longer toast the mallows on the fire as we'd eaten them all.The moral of the story is that Bao steamed buns are slightly harder to play Chubby Bunnies with, needless to say, I bet you've probably wanted to. Although the little steamed poppets look like teeny, you'd probably fit about 4 into a standard sized mouth, so it's potentially an expensive game at £5-£6 quid-a-pop. Another little trip down memory lane incurred after trying Bao's darling little trotter nuggets. I'd have fayre like trotters at my nan's as a kid. Delicious and she'd laugh her bloomers off at their reintegration as 'hawte kwizine' today. I'd often stay with her and I fondly recalled having the them for tea on my return home from camp sodden with mud and full of flu. Now due to that dratted Jamie O having outlawed anything nugget or twizzler shaped, I haven't been able to get my hands on anything processed or nugget-like since. So thank you Bao for taking me on a trip down memory lane, to a time when nuggets were a currency and nothing to be ashamed about. I'm proud to have been one of the first in the queue to get served. Only a mere half an hour of an undignified wait to get in at 5.30, much like waiting in a school lunch line. In Soho. Whilst cool people with table bookings elsewhere walked by in bemusement of the line forming behind me. So the last little touch I liked, was what really I needed to get me in the spirit of things: sitting on child sized furniture and eating kiddie portioned food at adult prices. Although I loved the coat pegs on the walls! It've been a nice touch if once I was through the door, they could have labeled it with my name and a picture of my nursery school totem creature; the unicorn. Now, where can I find an old fashioned sweet shop so that I can remark on how a packet of foam shrimps, cola cubes and a few flumps no longer cost 25p but the amount I'd spend on a dessert at a La Gavroche. Chubby Bunny Cheeks anywhere else, anyone?I'm game.

FsPhh3b152v-vBMJ5oVUOQ.text: Super popular bao place in Soho. Lines are usually queued across the street but moves quickly. Recommend the pork belly bao, mixed greens and mushroom appetizer. Other dishes were good as well: lamb bao, fried chicken and wonton chips with eggplant.

xaqukIghqqETjgEWCH-fpg.text: I wanted to love this place but found the food to be just OK. Menu needs a bit more variety.  My favorite was the fried horlicks dessert Bao - WOW.

8PyzWax8d9vYap4Lm1ZwgQ.text: Having had the luxury of a second visit to Bao, I have been able to try some more tasty bites: the House Pickles were intriguing but a couple were a little too sharply sour for my taste, the Pig Blood Cake was sumptuously soft and well matched with the perfectly round egg yolk (although I am told it is very much like black pudding, which I have not tried before), the Trotter Nuggets are well proportioned (you get four decent sized pieces) and they are lightly crispy on the outside with an interesting mix of meat, fat and possibly potato on the inside, the Scallop with Yellow Bean Garlic was bursting with flavour and served up a good whole scallop immersed in a delicious dressing, the Aubergine Wanton Crisp seems a bit of a bizarre combination as the fried wanton is simply provided separate from a small dish of aubergine (nevertheless the aubergine is pleasantly topped up with herbs with a bed of spice underneath), and finally the Daikon Bao was a decent vegetarian option for Bao as the Bao is the same white fluffy Bao as for the meat varieties and the Daikon is a block of crispy and subtly fragrant turnip on a bed of herbs and accompanied with a smoky sauce.

B_jUfmMc7gNOXzCd-ZdB5w.text: So so sooooo good! Worth the half hour wait on the sidewalk outside. Try EVERYTHING!We were a group of four, which allowed us to try every bun and most of the small plates. We loved it so much we had a second round of most things, including the buns. So sooooo good.

Htt5Ky3FdhJeUwL9r5OtLA.text: Delicious! I had the classic bun and the pork confit bun and both were well worth it. I also had the sweet potato fries as my side, very crispy and a good sized portion. I tried the peanut milk out of pure curiosity as I had never had it before and was intrigued. It's exactly what it sounds like.The space is small, but the service is excellent. The waiting queue is across the street which is slightly unusual, but the hostess is very good at keeping track of the queue and letting people know realistically how long the wait might be.

2yJMpuTKtm3J47e_AnXFCQ.text: Bao is a popular place at the moment, and it's quite small inside, so there was a queue outside, but the line went along quickly.The main attraction is the 'bao' - a steamed white fluffy bun with meat or veg inside.  I went for the daikon one (for vegetarians) and it was good, although was slightly dry and could've done with some more sauce on it.Everything else on the menu seemed interesting.  I had some sweet potato fries in a lovely plum sauce and also some interesting pickles I had never seen before, including one that was a bit like a soft cherry tomato.  Strange and cool!Next time I'm going to try the fried horlick's ice cream bao...

JqUEhFBsiPp_DWn7gH6X1Q.text: Always want to try this place cuz it's been so famous since it opened.Just like what I imagined, the queue was really long even it was a Thursday. We waited around 1 hour for table for three.The food is nice. Really like the fried chicken bun as well as the lamb one I ordered.Was thinking of giving it a 5star but we waited too long. Really hope they can open another one somewhere else.

cA_ou-QAnsjPTok3budWjg.text: I have never queued for a restaurant in London, I just don't believe in it. It was going to take a special special place to make me stand in the streets. For 1 hour.I had visited the stand in Hackney several times and have bleated to anyone who would listen about the dreaminess of their fried chicken and how excited I was about their first restaurant. I am happy to announce that this place is freakin' awesome and totally worth the wait! I liked the minimalist interior, the tight seating hardly distracts you from the amazing food, I sat looking at the toilet for goodness sakes! I was still extremely happy to be there.We ate many things.....scallops in glorious garlic sauce, fried chicken is still great, trotter nuggets were cute and yummy, the lamb bao was delicious with many layers of flavour and fun. We also enjoyed the guinea fowl rice but wanted to eat everything on the menu, twice over! The only thing I didn't enjoy was the sweet potato fries, they just seemed abit random and didn't have the same flavour offerings as anything else.Peanut milk is offered on the menu and we were advised to drink it with the savoury food....which didn't work at all. However, as a separate drink? Delicious. We also tried the cold foam tea, so weird, but nice.Service was good, friendly, informative, interested, not slow at all, the table space is not huge, so actually, dishes coming out in a staggered manner is perfect.People were asking us if the food was good, what type of food is was and how long we had waited for whilst we queued. My advice? Come to Bao, eat, enjoy and feel happy. I can't wait to come back. Just at a quieter time!

v7jDqJmIJ-Gw6NdNt_ddYQ.text: I had heard about BAO online and had two friends that lived in shanghai and Singapore who wanted to try it out so we headed down to Piccadilly Circus to look for the famous bao restaurant. We had a sneaking suspicion the line across the street was not for the pub or the health food shop on either side of it, and a very friendly waitress confirmed that we would need to wait in line for about 45 minutes, as they had just opened and the whole first wave of people had to finish eating. As we were on a mission for bao, we decided to stick it out. It was a sunny day so waiting in line wasn't too bad, and we were given a menu to look at while waiting. The only item they were out of was the fried ice cream. Once seated, I admired the minimalist decor and efficient ordering system (you mark what you want on a paper and hand it in- they were great about me writing in a request for no kimchi on my fried chicken bao!) I highly recommend the sweet potato chips with the sauce and the peanut milk. My friends had the classic bao and the pork confit and seemed to love the pork. All looked amazing though! Another girl that came with us had a nut allergy, and the staff were wonderful about giving her safe foods and passing the information along to the kitchen as well. Amazing and fast, efficient service (once inside) and really friendly, cool waiters and waitresses! Love it and will be coming back!

BBmq0DTW51-Ls43PerjHQQ.text: Brought here by another yelped initially,  I thought I would return for some Bao classics. That was rather nice and they had lots of other finger food which I was surprised could fill me up, but it did. The sake was pretty poor though and quite expensive I thought. Overall it appears this little number is well know tourist destination spot and u may have to queue a little outside. You can take in the public health history of the place as the snowy pub will inform those in the know.

YrSjrLIFz1QLDNF6kNKbKw.text: Wonderful place! If you get there 10 mins before opening, will be seated straight away. Only a lil bit pricey but the service and not to mention Bao, defo worth the money indeed.

Q7_RMMvnY54tPRd45VsJjw.text: Just a few things so you know what you're getting in for. 1. Waiting: The place itself is tiny, so unless you come at a really random time you'll probably have to wait a bit. The line is across the street in front of a sign with their logo. The wait goes by relatively fast though. 2. Fast: The food comes out super fast once inside - with that little space their service is top notch. While in line you might be given a menu to mark down what you want to quicken the pace.3. Tiny: The place, the food. The bathroom itself is a little larger than an airplane toilet. Make sure you order enough - the bao's are about the size of your palm. I ordered a tea, and the pot was about the size of a Bao as well. Seriously have never been served a drink so miniscule before. You just look at it and are you like - is this a toy? What. 4. Satisfaction: Everything I got here was very good. I would recommend getting the Confit Bao, Pig Blood Cake, Sweet Potato Crisps and Horlick Ice Cream.

fjuYquD-LA3c5k5AXffIuw.text: Bow down to the Bao! This tasty stop is guaranteed to be a hit. Expect a line (even if it's freezing out). It's just that good. You'll HAVE to try their ice cream bao. It's so unique and you'll love every bite!

Dc8b3Q_kaAvQ0xO6Wx8fOg.text: Worth a try, at least once. I showed up at opening for dinner time. Although the restaurant was empty, the hostess asked me to queue across the street. I waited in the queue for 30 seconds and then the hostess retrieved me from across the street to sit at the bar. I found humor in how technical Bao approached seating tables. The taste is great, but the portions are small. There's also an automatic 12.5% service fee added to the bill. Cool logo and experience, but unless you spend over 20GBP, you will be hungry later.

jhR3OKeuyifvJLzvjqqO7w.text: I went here with a small group of friends - one of whom who had already been. As such, we got a good idea of what this place was about. According to my friend, Bao started out as a small-time market seller who received financial funding only recently. The result is that Bao is the hottest Taiwanese "designer" cafe in London currently and the extraordinary queue across the street confirms. Apparently, there was a two-page spread in the Telegraph on how this business grew. Queuing can take as long as a half hour for 4 people but it's worth the wait so plan in advance! They do not take bookings. The menu itself consists of "small eats", "Xiao Bao's" (Small Bread) and "sides". Unsurprisingly, many people come here to try the "Bao's". The menu doesn't lie when it says the Bao's are small - I can probably eat one in less than 2 minutes so it is advisable that you get at least 3 or 4 to be satisfied or a combination of different dishes. Being new, I was recommended the "Classic" which was a Bao filled with Pork Confit. Admittedly, it tasted more like pulled pork but it wasn't disappointing as the meat was so very tender and surprisingly quite light. I liken the Bao to the taste of Mantou (饅頭) so expect it to be very sweet tasting.The next Bao I tried was Lamb Shoulder with picked chilis - this was much nicer so I highly recommend this one. The spiciness is average and the lamb comes in tender chunks. Most definitely, I'll be getting this next time again. I read a previous Yelp review to try the Sweet Potatoes I was keen to try these. I don't find it anything special but it's a good dish to share around the table as a starter. Note that these are fried.  I think my favourite dish was the Beef and Daikon soup. It's light and very brothy - you don't get anything in the soup besides 3 small daikon sticks which tastes like they're supposed to taste like. The soup itself is very tasty with just the right amount of salt added and an explosion of sweet onion.

Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Beef soup with Daikon
Photo of BAO - Soho - London, United Kingdom. Chicken rice, Taiwanese style

s3Q83_A_8k-21zBCTRieTQ.text: If you want to eat at BAO store then prepare to queue. The shop is small so no surprise there is a queue. It is defintely not suitable for large groups here but a place to consider for one or two people.When you finally do get a seat, you would place your order by filling in a order form and hand it to one of the staff. The menu is broken in to three section - small plates, bao and sides.The drinks are on a separate menu and there are a selection of hot or cold oolong tea. The hot oolong tea is served in a small clay teapot. You will see the staff use a timer to brew each tea to work out when its ready to seve.When you visit BAO you have to order at least one of their bao which is what make them popular. There is different fillings to select including Fried Horlicks ice cream, which is deep fried bao (instead of the steam bao) with Horlicks ice cream.The steamed bao are soft and fluffy. The Classic Bao consist of braised pork with fermented greens and peanut powder. I preferred this over their Confit pork bao consisting of pork belly with a hot pork sauce and dried shallots. Eating bao can get a bit messy but don't freak because you will get wet tissue to wipe your hands. One of my favourite on the menu is their Scallops with yellow bean sauce which cost £3.50 and come served in its shell.Guinea Fowl Chi Shiang rice for £5.25 comes served in a small bowl which make it great size as a small plate. You can consider having one of these rice bowl and a bao, instead of muching yourself through lots of bao to get full and have your money draining away quicker.

ro_X3PrXSWDS7Y0xYCd7TQ.text: We came here around 6pm and surprisingly the line wasn't as long as I expected. About 6 couples waiting ahead of us. Which was about a 25 min wait. Quickly the line became very long - so try get there early if you don't wanna wait.Inside is very small. Although not cramped you're very close to other people. Not a problem for me, to be honest, but we were sat next the worst couple ever - the GF was too loud and actually the worst person I've encountered in a long time. I won't go into it too much butttttt they were annoying and distracting. :-)Staff are very friendly and everything is served quickly and promptly. #WinThe food is very good! Like very very good. The bao were tasty - we had the classic, lamb shoulder and fried chicken. I liked the classic a lot - tender pork with amazing flavours. The fried chicken was lovely also. I didn't enjoy the lamb as much - I thought it was a bit too spicy and oily. The beef strip was amazing! So tender and the flavours were subtle but delicious.The trotter nuggets were great. I'm guessing by the name it's pig foot meat that shaped my fried nugget. The sweet potato chips were good; chunky, battered and had a nice drizzle of hot sauce on them. Now here's my problem. The portions. And I am not a big eater. The bao are much smaller than the pictures suggest. I can easily pick one up with my forefinger and thumb. The server recommended 2 each but I think at least 3 is needed.The beef strip is not a strip but more tiny patches of meat - delicious delicious meat, did I mention. The trotter nuggets were okay - I think about 4 of small nugglets were in a portion. The chips - there were no more than 10 fries in there. C'mon! So to conclude, I like Bao. I really like the food. I just can't eat here unless I plan on eating afterward or if I eat 4-5 buns and 2 starters each.

dqZR0x5tvjkYdHm-DCdsaA.text: THIS PLACE WAS AMAZING. Hands down favorite meal in London so far (I've been here 2 weeks). A friend and I ventured over at around 2 pm and all the seats were full, but we were the only ones in line so we got seated after about 2 minutes. They immediately gave us the menu and we marked our orders on the provided paper (an interesting but efficient system).We ended up going for the classic bao, scallop, guinea fowl rice, and the fried ice cream (dessert) bao. The scallop wasn't my favorite - the sauce was too salty, and I personally don't think it was worth the 3.5 pounds (especially since the dish came with literally only one scallop). The guinea fowl rice was just alright, too - nothing special in my opinion.You might be thinking, then, why 5 stars? PURELY BECAUSE OF THE BAO. The classic bao - oh my god. It was absolutely FANTASTIC. The different components - braised pork, vegetables, peanut powder - combined incredibly, and the resulting taste was heavenly. The dessert bao was also really good (although I may be slightly biased because I'm a huge fan of sweets) - not AS good as the classic bao, but still definitely worth getting.Words cannot capture how much I loved both the classic and dessert bao (but especially the classic). I will for sure be back for more! Some notes for future visitors (which I highly encourage): the place is tiny, the service is quick, and the food (especially the sides) are slightly overpriced in my opinion for the serving size - with the exception of the baos. Which are completely worth it.

rCkJnQ_7W65OXmTX7tHL5g.text: Lovely little place serving lots of baos. We waited for an hour (AN HOUR) to get a table on a Friday evening. Once in, food was served fast, and things ran efficiently. We ordered the classic, pork confit and chicken baos. Also had the scallops, soup and aubergine as starters. Everything was rock solid -- appropriately delicate but also no-frills. I particularly liked my pork confit and chicken baos -- very flavourful with just the right combination of everything. Service was good, though I felt like some of the staff were bossy at times. I hope its early success doesn't get to their head. The place is quite small, so don't expect to linger their for any meaningful conversations. It's a bit of in-and-out type of place. Still, very good for baos.

WSKOP042YmV7u0ouG-POCQ.text: Ummm. Ok place if you deem for some Bao. Their food is not the most authentic Chinese food. It seems they are popular simply because they are good at making Insta pictures.

s7aVsghI6hrKl0Og7w4zfQ.text: Nice buns. The wait wasn't long as I beat the crowd. There always crowds but it's worth the wait. Classic buns and more sophisticated ones: you would definitely find one for your taste!

O74CMs-Im6jJfDw3lE7Hsw.text: The hyped up Taiwanese spot essentially serves what I would characterize as extremely tasty and elevated junk food. You can order almost the entire menu and not break the bank, which cannot be said for a lot of London living. Think Momofuku style fusions, but more reasonably priced. We already have a lot of fun and creative asian food spots here in Toronto, and London is starting to catch up in this domain...

hyv7bZ9bDgSPYfZH9HWYWg.text: Overated but good price. Queueing for 20 minutes before getting inside!Surprisingly the cheapest dish turns out to be the best one on the menu the classic bun and the sweet potatoes!I order myself blood pudding cake, classic and confit pork buns, sweet potatoes fries, grill mushroom with century egg and order the lamb bun and and fried chicken according to the waitress's suggestion which is a the worst two dishes among all the food! I love the sweet potatoes fries! Very unique! The blood cake at the first was good and then it become too fatty for me. The confit pork is not very flavourful as it was described by others. The lamb bun got nothing special and the chicken was tasteless

dYwcO0583xa2qR7-7ru3QQ.text: Must have been the third or forth attempt we tried to eat here.. The queue always put us off -(restaurant is so small that waiting is outside over the road where a Bao bus stop resides, I guess not to annoy the pub patrons next door). Even on a Monday, there was a queue before the lunch service! But must say it has Lived up to the hype! Super Tasty and interesting flavours.  We tried each and every bao available and was not disappointed.  Will have to order a fair few if you're there for dinner!  Drinks are tiny, but everything about the place is on point.  You see why the queues are long.  Many similar places are beginning to open up .. But these there the OGs!

olCBWDD5p5YfySk-jB-HEw.text: The First time I tried Bao burger , it was in Paris (Siseng restaurant) so when I saw in London they have a popular Bao place , for a food lover like me, I went and tried! And no disappointment at all! It was quite different to what I have tried but still as good! We had various little meals we shared : aubergine, fried chicken , scallop (difficult to share this one but still have tried a tiny bits) Guiana fowl rice and sweet potatoes fries. All were delicious and worth to try. Now the Bao: we all went for 2 Bao each as suggested by the waitress. We found them small when we saw them first but it was actually just right if you take into account the starters (if not for a big eater like me, it would not have been enough) . I have tried the classic pork Bao, the fried chicken Bao and the lamb Bao! All of them are EXCELLENT! They are really flavoured,  with the right amount of spice Tips: if you don't like spice, that might be difficult for you to eat as it might burn quite quickly but if you can handle a little bit of spice you will be fine! My favourite Bao was the classic one. The braised pork was sooooo good! Then the chicken, the sauce they put in it was really really good and the chicken perfectly fried. And I love the bread, like my friend said it is so soft and light , it's like eating a cloud (like she knows how a cloud taste ) And finally, we tried the ice cream Bao. That was original. Other tip: if you are like me with sensitive tooth and you can't bite on an ice cream, ask for a spoon to eat it. The ice cream was nice, the warm Bao that come with it as well but I would rather get another salty Bao than this dessert. Not a problem if you don't try it! Oh and I almost forgot the drink: I went for the cold tea with with peach and verbena. So refreshing, the perfect summer drink even if I went there end of September but who will say no to a fresh and refreshing  drink. That's it, I can't sell this place more than with this review and the pics!Final tip: go there either at 6.30 or after 8.30/9 on a Monday, the wait won't be long! And if you have to queue, do it! The food is worth the wait!

vH4BKjSxDLLOcaoXXwCHsQ.text: I had the fortune of trying Bao back when they were a stall, and was keen to try their permanent residence in Soho! Admittedly, the first time I went I tried all of their bao varieties and was actually a little underwhelmed, thinking that going permanent meant they'd sacrificed some of the quality of their food.On the second time though, we worked our way through the starters menu and I was blown away. The aged beef rump cap is hands down, one of the BEST single dishes in London I've tried.  The classic Bao is actually not their best I think, I much prefer the braised pork or the lamb!And avoid the drinks - overpriced for the size of the pot/glass you get! Besides that though, well worth getting in here if you can and don't mind queuing for the opportunity!

PFvO8DUJrEF7Dp_nEYtT6Q.text: Amazing food! A bit pricey but totally worth it. Small place, be prepared for long line ups. Highlights include; scallop, lamb bao, fried chicken and fried sweet potato. Everything was meticulously designed and was just delicious!!!

j0wyABZIX7HwI6Wc17pqPQ.text: Little pieces of melt in the mouth clouds filled with succulent  pork,  deep fried TENDER chicken breast or shredded minty lamb. The pepper sauce of the scallops is to die for and the aubergine chargrilled to perfection. My only problem was the ice cream bao, messy as hell!

8jJ7JeHe539iRoI9VkP-yw.text: I am Taiwanese. The food made me homesick. Indeed a must-try in London! Though we don't have some of the dishes back in Taiwan, all dishes tasted pretty well, especially the Classic Bao. I have it all the times around my house in Taipei.
